titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: I attended this morning at St. John’s Church, where Mr Hawley read the Morning service for the fourth Sunday after Trinity, and Mr Butler of Troy New-York read the first part of the Communion service, and preached from 1. Corinthians 1. part of v. 21—“the world by wisdom knew not God” Mary and her daughter Louisa were at Church with me— At 5. O’Clock afternoon I attended again at St. John’s Church where Mr. Hawley read the service but I was the only respondent of part of it, and not twenty persons present at any part— Mr Hawley gave out two hymns to be sung but there were no singers, and no performer on the Organ, and Mr Hawley’s exhortation substituted for a Sermon of not of five minutes duration— Between the two services there had been a long continued and very severe thunder-storm, in which the clouds in conflict seemed for a full half hour to be suspended immediately over our heads— In the leisure of the day I was reflecting upon the Resolutions and measures which it might be proper to adopt on the occasion of the decease of La Fayette— I moved the appointment of the joint-Committee yesterday because I felt that my position required it specially of me more than of any other member of Congress—but having done that, my principle will be to let others do all the details and propose myself, nothing All may possibly thus go on smoothly— But if I should propose Resolutions written by myself, the instant they should be read in Committee, the Spirit of verbal criticism would be kindled in the joint Committee, and there might be two days debate without coming at last to a Conclusion— I was well advised yesterday even in leaving the number of the Committee on the part of the House in blank— Five and seven had been named, but one from each State was more acceptable to the House; and as it is, multitudes of members will be disappointed, in not being themselves upon the Committee— Mrs Frye was here this morning after the service was over.

The Committee on the part of the House to consider and report suitable tokens of respect to the Memory of Genl La Fayette was announced on the reading of the Journal— I was Chairman—the names of the members on the part of the Senate 13. were afterwards communicated— I notified a meeting of the Committee at 1/2 past 9 to-morrow Morning at the Chamber of the Committee of Commerce of the House. This was petition day—but Polk moved to suspend the rules after two O’Clock, to take up his Bank-deposit Bill Question divided—vote to suspend the rules carried— But to take up that Bill not two thirds— The time till 2 O’Clock was wasted in violent altercation Speeches between Burges and D. J. Pearce of Rhode Island upon Resolutions from the Legislature of that State—both touched upon the Hartford Convention— At two the Harbour Bill was taken up, and under a running fire for and against internal improvement till near 9 at Night, with the Episode of a very heavy Thundergust was carried by a final vote of 107 to 46— The appropriation of 29000 dollars for Surveys voted down upon my Speech the other day was now carried 92 to 82— All by the change of Beardsley and the New-York Van Buren members—Jones of Georgia—Felder of South-Carolina and especially Wise of Virginia taunted them upon it bitterly Beatty of Kentucky, Ewing of Indiana and other western members flew the course, because they could not carry special favourite improvements of their own— The Appropriation for surveys was the tug for life and death—the question of engrossment was carried by an increased majority; and the passage of the Bill by more than two to one. I saw Mr Webster twice in the House, and once in the Senate about the Meeting to-morrow of the La Fayette Committee, and W. S. Archer at my request drew up Resolutions to offer. I came home pleased with the result of the day.

24. V. Tuesday. At 1/2 past 9 this Morning the joint Committee of the two Houses of Congress on the honours to be paid to the memory of General La Fayette, met in the room of the Committee of Manufactures of the House of Representatives—24 Members of the House and 13 of the Senate all present except Joseph Duncan of Illinois— The Resolutions drawn yesterday by W. S. Archer were presented, and Mr Clay offered one embracing the substance of the three— Propositions were offered for dressing in mourning the Chairs of the Vice-President and of the Speaker of the House— Mr Calhoun offered a resolution that I should be requested to deliver an Oration upon the Life and character of Genl La Fayette before both Houses of Congress at the next Session— There was little discussion upon the Resolution and the two Chairmen, Mr Webster and myself were authorised to draw them up and report them— This was done with the aid of Mr Archer, and in the Evening I reported them to the House, where they were accepted—read three times and unanimously passed. In the House there was some discussion and much manoeuvering to take up the Bank deposit Bill in preference to the Fortification Bill— The Bank Bill prevailed and after excellent-senseless Speeches from Coulter and Stewart of Pennsylvania, Jones of Georgia, and M’Vean of New-York, Miller of Pennsylvania moved the previous question which was seconded and carried—and the Bill as reported by the Committee of Ways and Means passed the second and third reading after a Call of the House, by a vote of 112 to 90. about 25 members of the House being absent intentionally to avoid voting— The Bill for pensioning the French Sailors wounded and the relatives of the two that were killed by the Salute at Toulon was taken up and reported by a Committee of the Whole on the Union, engrossed, read a third time and passed— M’Kinley of Alabama made an objection upon Constitutional grounds which I answered— The House refused him the yeas and nays upon the passage of the Bill— Adjourned about 1/2 past 6. The Senate this day rejected the nomination of Andrew Stevenson as Minister to London 23 to 22. of Roger B. Taney as Secretary of the Treasury 28 to 18. and confirmedButler as Attorney General without division— Evening visit from J. Connell

I received this morning a Letter from J. P. B. Storer a Clergyman at Walpole Masstts. enclosing a claim for increase of pension, of a Soldier named Jeremiah Smith, the papers of which I immediately took and delivered to the Secretary of War Cass, who promised to examine the case and send me an answer— At the House Francis Thomas Chairman of the Bank investigation Committee, asked the consent of the House to offer a Resolution that Friday next should be fixed to make the Majority Report of that Committee the special order of the day for next Friday— Thomas as usual made a speech and then a question was made by Watmough whether the motion should be considered by the House—considerable debate on this was allowed by the Speaker, until the question was taken by yeas and nays and carried for the consideration 87 to 65— I voted for the Consideration—but before the debate could be got afloat, the hour expired, and the orders of the day were called and a question arose between the fortification Bill, unfinished business, and three Bills reported by the Committee on Indian Affairs which had been made the special order for this day— The Speaker decided in favour of the special order, and the House went into Committee of the whole on the Union, on the three Indian Bills, they went through the Committee almost without a question, Horace Everett acting as Chairman, moved sundry petty amendments which pass’d without opposition—and I said nothing until the question of engrossment came upon the third Bill which was for assuming an absolute Government over all the Indian tribes, under colour of constituting them into a Western Territory. I enquired whether the Committee had examined the Constitutional right of Congress to pass such a Bill— Everett answered that no member of the Committee doubted the right— Vinton moved to postpone the Bill till the next Session— Then the House took a recess from 3. to 1/2 past 4 O’Clock— On returning Vinton supported his motion— I urged again the necessity of further time for examining the Bill H. Everett, Gilmer and Wayne sustained it— Archer joined in opposing it—and it was laid on the table— A bill for settling claims of Citizens of Georgia on account of Indian depredations before 1802 followed and was engrossed for a third reading against strenuous opposition by me— I laboured in vain— The House adjourned at ten O’Clock at Night.

78 years of age came with a subscription book for a fac simile copy of General Washington’s Accounts, for which I did subscribe— The House met at 10. O’Clock Sundry Memorials and Petitions were received and read—and resolutions were offered— I presented a Report of the Committee of Manufactures, on a Resolution of the Legislature of Vermont recommending an additional duty upon imported marble—referred to the next Session— Ordered to be printed and laid on the table— Connor moved the appointment of a select Committee of five, upon the Post-Office, to sit during the recess and make report to the House at the next Session—carried— There was a scuffle as usual to settle what business should be taken up; and at Mr Polk’s motion the appropriation bills were preferred. the General Appropriation Bill came in from the Senate with amendments which were discussed, after a Bill making appropriation to carry into effect certain Indian Treaties concluded during the present Session of Congress—this Bill passed with very little observation— Most of the Senate’s Amendments to the general Bill were adopted without debate— There was a long one regulating the compensation of Custom-House Officers, which Harper of Philadelphia strongly opposed but it prevailed— There was an Amendment, allowing members pay and mileage to E. R Potter who contested the Seat of A. Robbins as Senator from Rhode-Island—M’Kinley opposed and Pearce, Burges and I supported this Amendment, carried by yeas and nays,Recess, from 2 to 4. P.M— I stay and write a Letter to Charles. The Chair was resumed at 4— Committee of the whole— Ward of New-York in the Chair; and numerous Bills were rapidly carried through—the Bills for purchasing the Washington papers, for improvement of Harbours, and for Fortifications were reported and ordered to be engrossed— The Light-House bill too, 67. new Light-Houses was engrossed. Polk’s motion to strike out 100,000 dollars for fortifying George’s Island, in Boston Harbour was rejected by yeas and nays 73 to 80— Two out of three of the Bills reported by the Committee on Indian Affairs were passed— I opposed the Western Territory Bill which was laid on the table— The Georgia claim Bill came up, and the house adjourned for want of a Quorum at 1/2 past ten

Sundry Memorials and Petitions were presented by several members with the unanimous consent of the House, and ordered to be laid on the table and printed— A Resolution passed that the bronze Statue of Thomas Jefferson presented by Lieutenant Levi should be placed in the square on the Eastern front of the Capitol— A mu A multitude of Bills were driven along to engrossment for the third reading, and others laid on the table— Polk introduced a joint resolution for suspending the joint rule against sending new Bills from House to House, until ten O’Clock this Evening— I opposed it on the ground that this was not one of the last three days of the Session considering Sunday as much a Legislative day as any other—but the Resolution was adopted— A few minutes before two O’Clock the Georgia claims Bill came up at the third reading, and I asked for the yeas and nays upon it, adding some remarks which were interrupted by th arrival of the hour of two O’Clock— I dined with Mr Webster— Governor Lincoln, John Reed, W. Baylies, P. Sprague and Jos. Gales were the company— I was obliged to leave them to be at the House at precisely four O’Clock— Before a Quorum was formed sundry Resolutions were offered and other business was transacted— I finished my Speech against the Georgia claims Bill, and particularly showed that the allowance of Interest upon the claims of the States for the repayment of expenses incurred by them during the War was the reason, assigned by the President for putting his negative on the Bill for Settlement of the Accounts of the States passed two years ago, at the first Session of the 22d. Congress— To this part of my Speech Governor Lincoln replied, insisting that the veto upon the Bill allowing interest to the States was not for objection to the allowance of interest but to the manner in which it was computed—now in point of form this was true, but the substance of the objection was to the allowance of interest at-all— The resistance to this Georgia Bill was however vain, for the previous question was called and the Bill passed—all the drilled parties being retained in its favour, and there is not a party in the house that votes upon measures by their merits alone— Other business ensued, and it was between nine and ten at Night when the house adjourned, and little short of eleven when I got home— Conversation this morning with Mr Dorr.

Mr Dorr recently appointed Consul of the United States to Buenos Ayres, and with whom I had a long conversation in the lobby of the House yesterday, called on me this morning, and I lent him the pamphlet officially published by that Government on the controversy between them and us concerning the transactions at the Malvinas or Falkland Islands— He is to take it with him, and then to send it back to me, or another in its place— The House met at ten O’Clock and were engaged all day in reading and passing with precipitation, a great multitude of Bills public and private— Many of the members are gone—others are going to-morrow and Monday The rule of not sending new Bills, between the two Houses the last three days of the Session, or of sending no Bills the last day to the President was at last totally suspended— At two O’Clock the recess took place, and I went and dined with W. S. Archer at Dowson’s—the Senators Calhoun, Preston and Leigh of Virginia were there; but the adjournment of the Senate was only for one hour, and at 3 O’Clock, they left Archer and me in tete a tete— Very soon after 4. we returned to the house where they were proceeding in a call, which was soon suspended and a vote of thanks to the late Speaker Andrew Stephenson passed by yeas and nays 99. to 59. R. M Johnson had asked this morning the suspension of the rule to offer the same Resolution, and failed; for want of two thirds— They now put up with a majority— Just before Midnight the Senate adjourned— I moved and urged an adjournment of the House but in vain— I gave notice, that if there should be no Quorum on Monday I would move a Call of the House, and that the names of the absentees should be entered on the Journals— They continued passing some Bills and laying others on the table, till past two Sunday Morning; upon a call for a vote then there were found less than a hundred members present Patton of Virginia proposed to pass six Bills in a lump by one question which I utterly opposed and declared I would consent to take no vote without a quorum present.— The House then adjourned— I took Coll. Watmough home to his lodgings at his wife’s father’s, Mr Stephen Pleasanton’s, and reached my own home just before a heavy shower at the dawn of day.

It was about three this morning when I found my bed, and taking some repose I rose unusually late— Mr Fendall called upon me; he left with me a Richmond Compiler, containing a severe attack upon a new sally of Richard Rush against the United States Bank, and to the honour and glory of President Jackson— It is a paper in a public Journal, seven or eight columns in length, which I have not seen The Article in the Compiler is wormwood, and I suppose written by Fendall himself— I attended worship this morning at the Presbyterian Church, where Mr Smith preached from Zechariah 13.1. “In that day there shall be a fountain opened to the house of David and to the inhabitants of Jerusalem for sin and for uncleanness.”— The meaning of this passage is somewhat obscure— By a fountain is perhaps intended a drain— At 5 in the afternoon at St. John’s Church Mr Hawley read the Evening prayer for the fifth Sunday after Trinity and preached from Matthew 11.29. “Take my yoke upon you, and learn of me; for I am meek and lowly in heart: and ye shall find rest unto your Souls.” There were scarcely ten men, and twice as many women at Church— There had been a very heavy Shower just before the service came on— Mr Hawley gave notice that there would be an Oratorio at the Church next Tuesday Evening at 8 O’Clock— After Church Mrs Adams and Mary rode out— I had time for musing and meditation, but not for suitable reading— Mr Southard the Senator from New-Jersey paid me an Evening visit to take leave. He is to leave the City on Tuesday to return to his residence at Trenton But he is on the Select Committee of the Senate, further to investigate the condition of the Post-Office, and they are to sit during the recess of Congress— The Report of the Majority of the Post-Office Committee of the Senate recently made had opened one of the floods of mismanagement, extravagance and corruption of the present Administration, such as never before was exhibited by this Government— But the public Robbers are so intrenched in the popular delusion that the exposure is more likely to ruin those who make it, than those whom it bares to public inspection.

The House met at 9 in the morning and proceeded to business— The Bill for making a grant of 36 Sections of Land to the Polish exiled emigrants came up— On an amendment made in the House to a Bill for the Senate, requiring payment in ten years for the granted Lands— The Senate disagreed to the Amendment— Clay of Alabama moved first to adhere and then to insist upon the Amendment. Then a motion was made to lay the Bill on the table—negatived by yeas and nays 48 to 107— Then the vote to insist on the amendment was carried.Next came a long debate on an Amendment from the Senate to the Potowmack Bridge Bill— The House disagreed to the amendment and the Senate afterwards receded from it— A great number of Bills were passed, and others were laid upon the table— A Bill for remitting the duties on a set of Bells; a donation to the Roman Catholic Church at St. Louis Missouri was much altercated. Polk made a Constitutional Question of it, and read a veto of Mr Madison, upon a grant of land to a Baptist Church somewhere— Sutherland, Cambreleng, Hardin, Beardsley, and I supported the Bill and it was carried by yeas and nays 67 to 55— This was the last appearance of a Quorum— The members successively left the House and departed by Stages full North and South— But Bills continued to pass between the two Houses with Amendments till 6 P.M— The last three Hours the House was idle, the Senate being engaged upon Executive business— Hawes played two or three boyish tricks, in which he was humour— The President retained one Bill—20000 dollars for improving the Wabash River— He sent a written unsigned Message, which Fulton of the joint Committee on the part of the House read, and which at my motion was ordered to be entered upon the Journal— It purported that he retained the Bill, doubting his power upon his views of the Constitution, to sign it— A Message was sent to the Senate that the House was ready to adjourn, and a similar Message was received from the Senate— About 1/2 past six both Houses adjourned, and the first Session of the 23d. Congress was closed— I came home with the Ladies, who were waiting for me in the Barouche, at the door— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were here in the Evening.
